The next big step will be a March 26 meeting wherein Qualcomm shareholders will get to vote on whether they want the takeover or not, according to a Reuters report. Broadcomâs effort is the latest and largest in a string of deals all about growing by acquisition. Itâs a bold approach admired by many, sometimes from a distance. It pours money into R&D and gets it back through sales of high-end products and licensing its patents. Itâs the latter part that has become the rub. Apple kicked off in January a major rebellion against Qualcommâs steep licensing fees, a battle still raging. Since then, another unnamed Qualcomm customer has also started pushing back on the fees. Broadcom and its Wall Street advisors see the opportunity to pounce. If they capture the mobile-chip giant, they will no doubt slice and dice it up as they have LSI, the classic Broadcom, and, as they will, Brocade. This will be a historic fight to watch over the next few weeks. Itâs the biggest proposed acquisition in the history of the semiconductor industry. In some ways, it even pales this weekâs somewhat bizarre bid of CVS for Aetna, claiming to reshape health care in America. For now, Broadcom is not increasing its $70/share bid for Qualcomm. Expect the war of words to intensify over the next quarter leading to the shareholder meeting, at which time, Hock Tan may sweeten his deal.
